newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico coffee survives cold, but next crop at risk.
newsitem.headline: Mexico coffee survives cold, but next crop at risk.

text.p: Mexico's 96-97 coffee crop appears to have survived the cold front hovering over the country's northern regions, but farmers told Reuters on Friday the recent weeks of cold could hurt the 97-98 harvest.

"The cold is the same as last year...when we had fiercely cold temperatures and damages were discovered later in this year's crops," said Sergio de la Vequia, a Veracruz farmer in one of the highest coffee plantations.
But weather forecasters said freezes in the northern region are unlikely to hurt next year's crops.
Weekend temperatures in coffee producing regions are forecasted to rise slightly, said Mike Palmerino of the independent Weather Services Corp.
"It should be a cool and wet weekend. Cold rains over the northern coffee areas this week could protect new buds flowering in the Spring from freezing temperatures," he added.

Coffee crops in the higher altitudes of Puebla and Veracruz states are traditionally most susceptible to cold weather. Output in the 94-95 season totalled 1.9 million 60-kg bags in Veracruz, and 617,310 60-kg bags in Puebla. Mexico's coffee crop
traditionally alternates between a higher yielding year and a smaller harvest. This 96-97 harvest is the cycle for the lower yielding year.
